channel.title: Interval Notation
channel.description:
Alright I've been in precal for about 3 weeks and Interval Notation is killing me... I've got sources to read up on it and I just am not understanding the domain and range part of the interval notation...
Could anyone help me out with intervals and the notation syntax?
I know it has to do with limits and I understand setting notation for a graph of 2 points such as where it decreases and increases, however when it comes to domain and range, and unions... I get lost.
For example, sometimes in square roots the domain has to be a real number, and they want the domain in interval notation. So I put (∞,∞) but the answer turns out to be (0,1).
Now the range, I again put (∞,∞) and it's right sometimes. I don't really know how the brackets go either, I thought the brackets as a starting point.
[9,∞) So it starts and nine and beyond? Or just at nine?
Also the unions... I know if the Union is a ∪ it's positive, right? And if its ∩ it's negative. What do they exactly mean tho, I read that it means, "or" but how is it or? Is it a set of x,y and then or this next set of x,y?
I really am trying to learn this interval notation to get it to make sense... but I just don't get it. Google is helping but I just... could anyone explain it a little more thorough? Thank you for your time and patience if you can help,
- Innovation

item.title: Interval Notation
item.dc:creator: @Innovation Innovation
item.description:
@Innovation wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:7, topic:346249”]Well for the brackets, [ and ] are hard brackets, ( and ) are soft brackets.

Hard brackets mean that the interval contains the end points. [4, 8] means that the interval actually contains 4 and 8, whereas (4, 8) means that the interval gets as close as possible, without containing the values. 4.000000000000000000000001, and 7.99999999999999.

[hr]

Using interval notation for the domain and range, is just a different way to write it.

Example:

Y = X[sup]2[/sup]

Domain: All real numbers or -∞ < x < ∞
Range: Y >= 0 or 0 <= y < ∞

Writing those an interval notation would be
Domain: (-∞, ∞) <-- We use soft brackets because we can never reach infinity
Range: [0, ∞) <-- Hard bracket saying we include 0

[hr]

Union is like saying that the interval doesn’t include some value(s)

(-∞, 0) U (0, ∞) means that the interval is from negative infinity, to infinity, but does not include 0.

I’ve never heard of positive or negative union though…[/quote]
Thanks. =) It makes better sense I wish I realized how easy it was earlier tho. xD

Thank you.

Read full topic

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:7, topic:346249”]Well for the brackets, [ and ] are hard brackets, ( and ) are soft brackets.

Hard brackets mean that the interval contains the end points. [4, 8] means that the interval actually contains 4 and 8, whereas (4, 8) means that the interval gets as close as possible, without containing the values. 4.000000000000000000000001, and 7.99999999999999.

[hr]

Using interval notation for the domain and range, is just a different way to write it.

Y = X[sup]2[/sup]

Domain: All real numbers or -∞ < x < ∞
Range: Y >= 0 or 0 <= y < ∞

Writing those an interval notation would be

[hr]

by negative union he means intersection

item.title: Interval Notation
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Well for the brackets, [ and ] are hard brackets, ( and ) are soft brackets.

Hard brackets mean that the interval contains the end points. [4, 8] means that the interval actually contains 4 and 8, whereas (4, 8) means that the interval gets as close as possible, without containing the values. 4.000000000000000000000001, and 7.99999999999999.

[hr]

Using interval notation for the domain and range, is just a different way to write it.

Example:

Y = X[sup]2[/sup]

Domain: All real numbers or -∞ < x < ∞
Range: Y >= 0 or 0 <= y < ∞

Writing those an interval notation would be
Domain: (-∞, ∞) <-- We use soft brackets because we can never reach infinity
Range: [0, ∞) <-- Hard bracket saying we include 0

[hr]

Union is like saying that the interval doesn’t include some value(s)

(-∞, 0) U (0, ∞) means that the interval is from negative infinity, to infinity, but does not include 0.

I’ve never heard of positive or negative union though…
